message: I'm trying to figure out where the heck this statement is coming from, so I went to look for the source for update_attributes, and I found the following:
First piece of the puzzle; update_attributes was moved to ActiveRecord in Rails 3
I'm struggling with a bug right now where using update_attributes on an inherited class with set_table_name is breaking.  It's generating an sql query like this:
"This method is deprecated on the latest stable version of Rails. The last existing version (v2.3.8) is shown here."

ruby-1.9.2-p180 :012 >   version
 => #<UserVersion id: 33, versioned_id: 3, versioned_type: "User", user_id: nil, user_type: nil, user_name: nil, modifications: {"address"=>"191929 Rainbow St.", "city"=>"Triptronic", "created_at"=>2011-03-29 00:38:53 UTC, "email"=>"john@example.com", "id"=>3, "name"=>"Fresh john", "phone_number"=>"123 456 7890", "updated_at"=>2011-03-29 01:00:56 UTC}, number: 16, reverted_from: nil, action: "destroy", tag: "", created_at: "2011-03-30 18:37:08", updated_at: "2011-03-30 18:37:08"> 
ruby-1.9.2-p180 :013 > version.update_attributes(:tag => "", :action => "hello")
ActiveRecord::StatementInvalid: SQLite3::SQLException: no such column: user_versions.tag: SELECT  "versions"."id" FROM "versions" WHERE "versions"."versioned_id" = 3 AND "versions"."versioned_type" = 'User' AND ("user_versions"."tag" = '') AND ("user_versions".id <> 33) LIMIT 1
in a nutshell it's performing a SELECT statement referring to the incorrect table; the table for a UserVersion object is user_versions, not version
which confuses  me as this apparently deprecated method is still used by the scaffolding generated controller
Next piece; it has to do with the fact that I'm recreating some associations by restoring a deleted object, and the behavior of autosave...
